summary:
I’m an experienced data scientist with almost a decade of work in both industry and academia, using data to solve real-world problems and help businesses make better decisions. I specialize in analyzing data, building predictive models, and applying machine learning to create insights that improve performance.

I have successfully led projects and teams, turning complex data into easy-to-understand information that executives and non-technical people can act on. My work has spanned industries like energy, retail, and public policy, where I've driven initiatives that led to significant improvements.

I’m passionate about working collaboratively and communicating technical information clearly. If you’re looking for a data professional who can blend academic knowledge with practical experience to create results, let’s connect!
headline: Machine Learning Manager @ Tailored Brands, Inc. | PhD

experience.description:
Conducted risk assessment and scoring of NY ISO energy generators, including assessing the variability of renewable energy sources and emissions constraints in the system's operation, for the Advanced Research Projects Agency-Energy (ARPA-E).

This involved evaluating the potential risks and challenges that various energy generators, particularly those utilizing renewable energy sources, may face in their integration and operation within the NY ISO grid. This required a deep understanding of the technical and regulatory aspects of renewable energy and its integration into existing energy systems. Additionally, I evaluated the emissions constraints and regulations to further improve the reach of the project

The assessment also required the use of data analysis, optimization techniques, software development, and modeling techniques to simulate and predict the performance and potential issues of different energy generators under different conditions. The results were used to provide recommendations to ARPA-E on the potential risks and opportunities for the integration of renewable energy sources in the NY ISO grid. This role required a strong understanding of energy systems and regulations, as well as experience with data analysis, optimization, software development, and modeling.
experience.title: Postdoctoral Scientist

experience.description:
-Led the company's Labor Hour Optimization project creating a detailed mapping of the effect of the results in the company KPIs and creating levers to control the optimization towards the company objectives. 

-Led the company's sales risk management for macroeconomic scenarios in uncertain conditions. This involved identifying potential risks to the company's sales performance, such as changes in market conditions or shifts in consumer behavior, and developing strategies to mitigate those risks.

-Developed the company's discount marketing targeting strategy and policy. This involved analyzing customer data and market trends to identify the most effective ways to target discounts and promotions to specific segments of customers. 

-Conducted sentiment analysis on the industry perspective of the economy and the status quo of the company. This involved using natural language processing techniques to analyze large amounts of data from news articles, and other sources to understand how industry experts and analysts were perceiving the economy and its potential impact on the company's operations. 

-Utilized machine learning methods for conversion rate optimization and analytics. This involved using techniques such as regression analysis, decision trees, and neural networks to analyze customer data and predict which actions are most likely to lead to conversions (such as sales or sign-ups).

publications.name: Stochastic cost-benefit analysis to assess new infrastructure to improve the reliability of the natural gas supply
publications.description: The reliability of a natural gas system involves the capacity of the supply, transportation, storage, and distribution system to provide service without short-term interruptions in the event of contingencies. Typically, increasing the gas supply reliability implies diversification of gas sources, transportation redundancies or larger gas storage capabilities. In addition, the combined operative uncertainty of the transportation pipeline and gas supply are not considered when assessing the impact of new infrastructure seeking to increase the gas supply reliability. To overcome these deficiencies, we propose: (i) a stochastic cost-benefit analysis; (ii) a pipeline contingency model using topographical, societal (violence) and pipeline information; and (iii) a supply contingency model of scheduled and unscheduled maintenance. Moreover, we consider both the gas supply and transportation uncertainties using a Monte Carlo simulation and an optimization model; furthermore, the expected cost-benefit is estimated. Our methodology is applied and calibrated to the Colombian natural gas system to estimate the expected cost-benefit of a new pipeline: Jobo - Medellín. The results show that the expected benefit-cost ratio (BCR) of this pipeline is 2.02 and that the probability of having an economic benefit greater than the cost is equal to 99.0%.

publications.name: Virtual Power Plant Day Ahead Energy Unit Commitment
publications.publisher: Hawaii International Conference on System Sciences
publications.description:
In this article, we present a model for the interaction of distributed energy resources (DER) with
the electricity system, using reinforcement learning. Our method relaxes the requirements for information necessary to train and engage in Pareto improving trading, and can directly incorporate the inherent intermittency of variable renewable energy sources. The distributed resources include consumers of electricity, energy storage systems, and variable renewable energy. We modify the algorithms to improve the scheduling of the resources. In our empirical application, we use data
from Colombia subject to large variability due to El Niño Southern Oscillation and illustrate the use of the model under large variations in the data used to train the model.

member.occupation: Machine Learning Manager @ Tailored Brands, Inc. | PhD

publications.name: simulation of photo-voltaic power generation using copula autoregressive models for solar irradiance and air temperature time series
publications.description: We propose a methodology for synthetic generation of solar irradiance (shortwave flux) and air temperature time series using copula functions. The use of copulas for the simulation gives flexibility to represent the serial stochastic variability of the solar irradiation and the air temperature affecting the photo-voltaic (PV) panel energy output. Moreover, it allows to have more control on the desired properties of the time series, not only in the temporal and cross-dependencies, but also in the marginal distributions. We use mixtures of zero mass adjusted density distributions to assess the nature of solar irradiance, alongside vector generalized linear models for the bivariate time series time marginal distributions. We found that the copula autoregressive methodology used, including the zero mass characteristics of the solar irradiance time series, accurately models the stochastic phenomena. Experimental analysis with observed data substantiates the usage and convenience of the proposed methodology to model solar irradiance time series and solar energy across the northern hemisphere, southern hemisphere and equatorial zones. These results will improve the understanding of the fluctuating nature of solar irradiance and also help to understand the underlying stochastic process of photo-voltaic energy production.

member.occupation: Machine Learning Manager @ Tailored Brands, Inc. | PhD

publications.name: Spatiotemporal correlation study of traffic accidents with fatalities and injuries in Bogota (Colombia)
publications.description:
Highlights
•The attention to traffic-related accidents by local authorities requires the modeling and forecasting of events, spatially and temporally defined.

•We use data from the traffic police department (Bogota) about incidents with injuries or fatalities (2013–2016).

•We locate each event in spatial coordinates and crossed the observations with exogenous variables (climate, seasonal, and road properties).

•We model the spatiotemporal stochastic process for accidents using a Log-Gaussian Cox model given its flexibility as it enables the use of fixed and random effects.

•The results of this study permit the identification of factors that increase the risk of accidents, and the location of critical zones in the city.

member.occupation: Machine Learning Manager @ Tailored Brands, Inc. | PhD

publications.name: Copula Autoregressive Methodology for Multi-lag, Multi-site Simulation of Rainfall
publications.description: This work presents a methodology for the synthetic generation of rainfall time series based on the copula autoregressive methodology with multiple lags and for multiple sites. In this model, the multivariate time series is decomposed using pairwise copula functions to represent the whole cross-dependence, spatial and temporal structure of the data. We explore the advantages of using this nonlinear method over more traditional approaches that as an intermediate step transform the data to a normal distribution or usually omit the zero mass characteristics of the data. The use of copulas gives flexibility to represent the serial variability of the observed data on the simulation and allows for more control of the desired properties. We use discrete zero mass density distributions to assess the nature of rainfall, alongside a vector generalized linear model for the evaluation of time series distributions and their time dependence in multiple locations. We found that the copula autoregressive methodology models in a satisfactory manner the characteristics of the data, including its zero mass characteristics. These results will help to better understand the fluctuating nature of rainfall and also help to understand the underlying stochastic process.

member.occupation: Machine Learning Manager @ Tailored Brands, Inc. | PhD

projects.description:
(Abstract) The increasing interest in renewable energies strategies application and the path for diminishing the use of carbon-related energy sources have encouraged the development of novel strategies for the integration of solar energy into the electricity network. A correct inclusion of the fluctuating energy output of a photovoltaic (PV) energy system into an electric grid requires
improvements in the forecasting and simulation methodologies for solar energy potential, and the understanding not only of the mean value of the series but the associated underlying stochastic process. We present a methodology for synthetic generation of solar irradiance (shortwave flux) and air temperature bivariate time series based on copula functions to represent the cross-dependence and temporal structure of the data. 

We explore the advantages of using this nonlinear time series method over traditional approaches that use a transformation of the data to normal distributions as an intermediate step. The use of copulas gives the flexibility to represent the serial variability of the real data on the simulation and allows having more control on the desired properties of the data. We use discrete zero mass density distributions to assess the nature of solar irradiance, alongside vector generalized linear models for the bivariate time series time-dependent distributions. We found that the copula autoregressive methodology used, including the zero mass characteristics of the solar irradiance time series, generates a significant improvement over the state of the art strategies. These results will help to better understand the fluctuating nature of solar energy forecasting, the underlying stochastic process, and quantify the potential of a photovoltaic (PV) energy generating system integration into a country electricity network.
projects.title: Copula Autoregressive Methodology for Simulation of Solar Irradiance and Air Temperature Time Series for Solar Energy Forecasting

member.occupation: Machine Learning Manager @ Tailored Brands, Inc. | PhD

projects.description:
Session 17B: Analytics, Data Science and Data Mining 20.

(Abstract) The planning and location of resources for urban traffic management generate complex decision problems, given the uncertainty of variables that explain traffic behavior, the lack of data, and the large number of factors to be considered when creating optimal policies. In particular, the attention given to traffic-related accidents by local authorities requires the modeling and forecasting of events that are spatial and temporally defined.

In this study, we use data from the traffic police department in Bogota (Colombia) about incidents with injuries or fatalities between 2014 and 2016. We locate each event in spatial coordinates and crossed the observations with exogenous variables (climate, seasonal events, and road properties). We model the spatiotemporal stochastic process for accidents using a Log-Gaussian Cox model given its flexibility as it enables the use of fixed and random effects.

The results of this study are summarized in three main contributions: (i) identification of principal factors that increase the risk of traffic accidents and fatalities; (ii) identification of critical zones in the city that requires more attention; and (iii) a predictive tool to forecast accidents in the future, including the stochastic properties that can be used in a prescriptive model.
projects.title: Spatiotemporal stochastic analysis for traffic accidents in the city of Bogota.
